content.description: Start matched on a rail, big moves make this one move wonder very fun. Be careful on the descent as some of the choss on the back of this boulder broke off as I was downclimbing.
content.location: Near the rain gutter just down and left if you're coming uphill.

content.description: Start matched on a good edge, pull up to two cool slopers and the jug lip. Fun.
content.location: To the right of Training for Izabella.

content.description: Start with good feet and a decent left hand but everything from there on is small and sharp. Work the thin crack to the featured top-out. The thin fingers will help get you up to speed for Izabella.

This boulder has split perfectly in half, creating a "laser cut" crack that follows a slab to vertical face... starts out pretty sweet then gets a little spicy at the top as the finger crack turns to tips.  Crux is making that final reach to the top hold from a tips crack and no feet. Exiting early is possible but lessens the climb.
Awkward climb, but cool looking boulder. Lieback and jam up the right side.
content.location: Facing west, easy to spot.

content.description:
Huh. This is an odd one. The definition of a "non-climb".

Start right hand on the one good edge beneath the bulge and left on a sloper of choice. Get up the face.

Impossible to grade, may be better described as B2.
content.location: On the backside of The Bends.

content.description: A very clean slab with a cool, slight angle change. Start with a mantle then follow the left arete with friction feet. Other (and much harder) problems may exist going up the middle.
content.location: Walk north past Sweet n' Spicy.

content.description: When you see someone on a moped, you’d be tempted to laugh dismissively. However, once you saddle up and hit the throddle, I’m certain you’d have a smile on your face. That’s kinda how this crack is. Big jump start to a bucket then continue through very fun and technical movement to the top. It might be ugly but it sure is fun.
content.location: North side of the Rain Gutter boulder.

content.description: So round. So stupid. Pull onto a sloper dimple and a small right foot, start slapping up nothing and beached whale over the bulge. YAY.
content.location: Who cares.

content.description: Start on the jug and bust out the rad ~V7 boulder problem to get established at the base of the mini dihedral. Work up a cool sequence into a stance, move left to sketchy crimps and topout on the face. Sweet looking line that would get more stars if the top climbed as good as the start.
content.protection: Two TR bolts. Easy scramble up the backside to set up.
content.location: East facing mini dihedral on the Rain Gutter boulder.

content.description:
Start with your right hand on a cool, mini-hueco like crimp, and your left hand on a small, crimpy gaston, both at about head height. There is one option for your foot, and it’s a barely-there micro edge. Pull on, hope your foot doesn’t blow, and crank hard to make a left hand deadpoint to a good edge. Bring your feet up, smear, and hit another decent edge with your right hand. From there it’s easy climbing to the top but it’s not over just yet, as you’ll encounter a somewhat featureless top out, so be prepared to commit to a mantle/high step to finish things up.

Two stars for now; has the potential for three once the middle section cleans up a bit. A desperate start prevents this from being a four star classic though. Fortunately the start is on bullet rock.
content.protection: Pads, and a spot is always nice.
content.location: Slightly down and to the left of Rain Gutter.

content.description:
Awesome crimp line. Start on the small right hand crimp and a left sidepull. Pull on and fire to the good holds in the middle of the wall, then another long move to good crimps above the lip.

The only thing that deters from this line is the sketchy hold complex in the middle of the wall. They look a bit sketchy, but they weren't flexing. Pull down, not out.
content.location: Southeast of Rain Gutter, hidden in a corridor. Have fun.

content.description: Sweet line on perfect stone. Start on the left side of the rail feature and traverse right to a specific right hand hold, then lockoff to the sloper scoop at the lip. A true joy!
content.location: South of Rain Gutter.

content.description:
A rare style of climbing to come across in SD. Steep and powerful!

Sit start matched on the shelf. Move right to slopers, then straight up to a bad left hand sloper. Bump up the right hand arete into the stand start of Hulk Smash and hold a hard foot cut, then finish on Hulk Smash.

There is another variation done by David Vasko that goes at an easier grade (around V7), using a good but friable edge over left.
content.location: In the small corridor with Burn the Map and Hulk Smash. Down the hill from the obvious Rain Gutter.

content.description: Start with a weird pinch on the arête and a small crimp and get to the good scoop above the lip. Fun, powerful climbing with a juggy topout.
content.location: Behind Burn the Map, hundred yards downhill from Rain Gutter.

content.description:
A sweet power problem on great features.

Sit start with a nice jug on the right arete. Traverse across the face to the obvious side pull rail, then make a hard dead point straight up to an incut edge with the right. Hit the jug lip and mantle.
content.location: East of Hulk Smash about 2 minutes. It faces east.

content.description: A fun one.  Establish in the spoon by stepping off the rock or mantle-hopping in.  Smear up and left, using a crimp in the face to transition into the upper finger crack of Sweet and Spicy.
content.location: Directly right of Sweet and Spicy.

content.description: Climb the tall arête by starting on a smaller boulder below.  Continue on the tall, featured slab of the second boulder to the top of this two-pitch boulder problem.  Easy down-climb the backside.
A fun 2 move problem with cool holds on good rock. Start matched on the nice horizontal crimp, move to another crimp then the lip.
content.location: The north side of the big boulder sitting in the gully between the Summit Hill and Sub-Summit.

content.description: Tall with varied climbing, but the rock isn't the best. Would get another star with some more cleaning. Climb the hand to fist crack in the dihedral, to a lieback topout on the left. Be careful to avoid the loose rock near the top.
Short and hard compression.
content.location: In a cool cluster of boulders by The Bends. On the north end of Sub Summit.

content.description: Start at two head high crimp slots and either make a big lock-off move, or a full commitment dyno to the lip out and to the right. Hitting the correct spot on the lip is key to making or breaking it. The landing is tiered, and the moment you pull on and make the first move you gain quite a lot of air beneath you. Make sure to bring an extra pad or two, and a good spotter - if you don’t stick and hold the move you’re in for a drop! Once you’re in control of the first move, ascend the rest of the lip of the boulder for an easy, airy top out.
content.location: The Cheshire Boulder sits on the rim of a small crag, directly above the Fractured Boulder. This is easily approached from Hulk Smash, and is located approximately 100 yds East of it.

content.description: A clean, easy slab. Climb the center of the dimpled face, starting with a few thin moves to good holds. The right arete makes it easier.
content.location: To the left of The Spade.

content.description: Two large boulders form a corridor where you’ll find a south-facing vertical wall with three distinct patina plates. The movement is pure and somewhat demanding of both muscle and nerves.
content.location: Just uphill from Thin Ice on the ridge.

content.description: Sit start on the fist crack.  An unfortunate crimp makes the fist crack not very hard, just awkward.  Mount the ledge, then continue up the right leaning wide hands crack to the top, via unpleasant scooching.  Looks good, climbs bad.  Has both a bolge and a wolge.
content.location: Roughly 100 yards east of Before the Dive and Rain Gutter, if you really want to climb it.

content.description:
Sick one. It's really only two moves, but man they are some sick two moves! I was able to do them in isolation fairly quickly, but linking them together took a lot of work.

Sit start with the obvious crimp rail and a crappy undercling for the right hand. Pull on with poor feet and fire up to the sloper on the arete. Bring a foot up to the start hold and hit the sloping lip, and trend left to an easy mantle.

My grandpa would always call a really windy day a "blowass". The wind is always whipping at this boulder, which really helps give the temps necessary for this problem.
content.location:
In the same cluster as

The Bends.

Northern end of the Sub Summit area.

content.description: Ah...yes. I can't think of another boulder like this in SD. Start as far back as you can in the tunnel, underclinging the lip, and invert. Traverse the roof like this for about 20 feet, which feels secure until the shin-pump kicks in, then bust out the final pumpy lieback moves into good hand jams. Mantle into the big v-slot and take a few minutes to recover. You've got the bends...
content.protection: A pad is nice for back-slapping falls.
content.location: North of the obvious Rain Gutter Boulder, and almost directly east of the Summit Towers, in a big cluster of boulders perched on a small hill.

content.description: A right trending crack climbs more like a face climb with slopers and laybacking. Crux is near the top.
Techy face climbing up a beautiful quartz face! Tricky move to the lip.
Climbs the left arete of The Arkenstone on cool blocky holds. More of that awesome rock!
content.location: Arkenstone boulder.

content.description: Very low angle crack, hidden in a rain gutter feature on impeccable rock climbs smooth between two cracks.  Good trad lead for those just starting out. This boulder is easy to reference from as it's the largest and most obvious in that area.
content.protection: The crack is perfect fingers the entire way, amazingly.
